member.name: T:System.Text.StringHandler

summary.para:
Provides a handler used on two cases:
By the language compiler to process interpolated strings into instances.
As a builder to append and concatenate multiple s to a whole one.
Different with , this type won't contain any formatters to construct any custom format operations, i.e. using .

member.name: F:System.Text.StringHandler.GuessedLengthPerHole
member.summary: Expected average length of formatted data used for an individual interpolation expression result.

remarks.para: This is inherited from , and could be changed based on further data.

actually uses format.Length + args.Length * 8, but format.Length includes the format items themselves, e.g. "{0}", and since it's rare to have double-digit numbers of items, we bump the 8 up to 11 to account for the three extra characters in "{d}", since the compiler-provided base length won't include the equivalent character count.

para.i: The original value implemented by .NET foundation is 11, but I change it to 8.

member.name: M:System.Text.StringHandler.AppendLiteral(System.String)
member.summary: Writes the specified string to the handler.

remarks.para: is expected to always be called by compiler-generated code with a literal string. By inlining it, the method body is exposed to the constant length of that literal, allowing the JIT to prune away the irrelevant cases. This effectively enables multiple implementations of , special-cased on and optimized for the literal's length.

We special-case lengths 1 and 2 because they're very common, e.g.
' ', '.', '-', '\t', etc.
", ", "0x", "=>", ": ", etc.
but we refrain from adding more because, in the rare case where is called with a non-literal, there is a lot of code here to be inlined.

member.remarks:
This overload is expected to be used rarely, only if either:
a) something strongly typed as is formatted with both an alignment and a format.
b) the compiler is unable to target type to T.
It exists purely to help make cases from (b) compile. Just delegate to the T-based implementation.

member.name: M:System.Text.StringHandler.Grow
member.summary: Grows the size of .
member.remarks: This method is called when the remaining space in _chars isn't sufficient to continue the operation. Thus, we need at least one character beyond _chars.Length. will handle growing by more than that if possible.

member.name: M:System.Text.StringHandler.GrowCore(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Grow the size of to at least the specified .

remarks.para: Design notes:

We want the max of how much space we actually required and doubling our capacity (without going beyond the max allowed length). We also want to avoid asking for small arrays, to reduce the number of times we need to grow, and since we're working with unsigned integers that could technically overflow if someone tried to, for example, append a huge string to a huge string, we also clamp to . Even if the array creation fails in such a case, we may later fail in .

The pattern that reserved characters satisfied. All supported patterns are:

@"\t" To match a tab.

member.remarks: For example, if code is "Hello, world!".Reserve(@"\w"), the return value will only contain the letters, digits or the underscore character '_' (i.e. "Helloworld" as the result of this example).

member.name: T:System.SourceGeneration.DataMemberAttribute
member.summary: Indicates the attribute type that can be marked for a parameter, indicating the parameter is a -like one, telling the source generator that it should generate a property that references this parameter.
member.param: Indicates the member kind to be generated. You can reference the target value via type .

remarks.para: Begin with C# 12, we can define primary constructors for non- types. However, the parameter defined will be expanded as a real parameter in its containing constructor. The compiler won't create a binding field or property. We should define it manually. This attribute will solve this problem.
If you want to learn more information about this attribute type, please visit the metadata of the type.

member.name: M:System.SourceGeneration.DataMemberAttribute.#ctor(System.String)

member.param: Indicates the member kind to be generated. You can reference the target value via type .

remarks.para: Begin with C# 12, we can define primary constructors for non- types. However, the parameter defined will be expanded as a real parameter in its containing constructor. The compiler won't create a binding field or property. We should define it manually. This attribute will solve this problem.
If you want to learn more information about this attribute type, please visit the metadata of the type.

member.name: P:System.SourceGeneration.DataMemberAttribute.IsImplicitlyReadOnly
member.summary:
Indicates whether the generated field or property is implicitly read-only. If the property is , the generated data member (auto-impl'ed propertys or fields) will be modified by keyword if all following conditions are true:
The type is a , , (will be included in future C# version) or (will be included in future C# version)
The type is not marked with keyword
However, sometimes we should use non- member as fields or auto-impl'ed properties, but we cannot modify it. By setting the property with value, to avoid the source generator marking the generated member as .
member.remarks: This property is by default.

member.name: P:System.SourceGeneration.DataMemberAttribute.SetterExpression
member.summary: Indicates the extra setter expression. The expression is same declaration as auto-implemented properties. For example, if the property is declared as public object? Property { get; private set; }, the setter expression will be "private set". By default, this value will be , which means the target property does not contain a setter.

member.name: P:System.SourceGeneration.DataMemberAttribute.NamingRule
member.summary: Indicates the naming rule of the generated member name.

remarks.para:
The syntax of this property can be described as two parts:
A verbatim symbol @ ("At" symbol, may contain an extra character < or >: <@ or >@)
Characters used in a valid identifier

For example, if you want to set a generated property is named like xxxTargetProperty where the xxx is the name of the generated property, you can set this property as value "@TargetProperty". Then the generated property will be like:
public int ParameterTargetProperty { get; } = parameter;
By default, the naming rule is "_<@" for fields, and ">@" for properties.

member.name: P:System.SourceGeneration.DataMemberAttribute.MembersNotNull
member.summary: Indicates the member names becoming not when this generated member is or .
member.remarks:
The syntax of this property can be described as two parts:
Boolean value literal
Member or parameter names
The complete expression is "(1): (2)". For example: ": property1, property2". The generated member will be:
[MemberNotNullWhen(false, nameof(Property1), nameof(Property2))] public bool Parameter { get; } = parameter;
where property1 and property2 are supposed to be two parameters marked this attribute.

member.name: P:System.SourceGeneration.DataMemberAttribute.GeneratedMemberName
member.summary: Indicates the name of the generated member.

member.name: P:System.SourceGeneration.DataMemberAttribute.Accessibility
member.summary: Indicates the accessibility of the generated member.

remarks.para:
This property controls the case when you want to customize the accessibility of generated member. For example, the value is "private" or "Private", the generated member will automatically insert the accessibility modifier into property declaration:
private int Parameter { get; } = parameter;
By default, the accessibility is for fields and for properties.

member.name: P:System.SourceGeneration.DataMemberAttribute.RefKind
member.summary: Indicates the kind of the generated member.

remarks.para:
This property controls the case when you want to customize the reference kind of return value of the field or property. For example, the value is "ref readonly", the generated member will automatically insert the modifiers into declaration:
private ref readonly int _parameter = ref parameter;

By default, the kind should be suitable with parameter's declaration. If the parameter is defined without any modifiers:
(Supported for C# 12)
(Supported for C# 12)
(May not be supported for C# 12)
(May not be supported for C# 12)
(May not be supported for C# 12)
the generated member will automatically include a modifier if the modifiers don't include ; otherwise, no modifiers. If you want to set , you should manually set this property with value "ref readonly" value.
